find.-iname:

Explanations about Options.-z:
Treat input and output data as sequences of lines, each terminated by a zero byte
 (the ASCII NUL character) instead of a newline. Like the -Z or --null option, this
 option can be used with commands like sort -z to process arbitrary file names.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Print only the matched (non-empty) parts of a matching line, with each such part on
 a separate output line.
Explanations about Options.-v: Invert the sense of matching, to select non-matching lines.

done

Explanations about Options.-d: A synonym for -depth, for compatibility with FreeBSD, NetBSD, MacOS X and OpenBSD.
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.
Explanations about Options.-depth:
Process each directory's contents before the directory itself. The -delete action
 also implies -depth.

Like -name, but the match is case insensitive. For example, the patterns `fo*' and
 `F??' match the file names `Foo', `FOO', `foo', `fOo', etc. The pattern `*foo*`
 will also match a file called '.foobar'.

ul_168181: Get all possible combinations of a word in lower/uppercase letters
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_168181: echo harley \
| perl -nle 'print "echo ",
                    join "",map { "{" . lc . "," .uc ."}" } split //' \
| xargs -I {} bash -c "{}"

echo harley \
| perl -nle 'print join "",map { "{" . lc . "," .uc ."}" } split //' \
| xargs -I {} bash -c 'for w in {};do echo $w;done'

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_13935395: converting string to lower case part of a string in bash shell scripting
Top-3 Scripts:
so_13935395: while read first second; do
    second=$(echo "$second" | tr [:upper:] [:lower:])
    printf '%s\t%s\n' "$first" "$second"
done < file.txt

typeset -l second
while read first second; do
    printf '%s\t%s\n' "$first" "$second"
done < file.txt

while read first second; do
    printf '%s\t%s\n' "$first" "${second,,}"
done < file.txt

Answers.MP Summary: presumably creating or updating package.json and running any other initialization-related operations. The init command is transformed to a corresponding npx operation as follows: · npm init foo -> npx create-foo · npm init @usr/foo -> npx @usr/create-foo · npm init @usr -> npx @usr/create Any  additional  options  will  be passed directly to the command, so npm init foo --hello will map to npx create-foo --hello. If the initializer is omitted (by just calling npm init), init will fall  back  to  legacy init  behavior.  It  will  ask you a bunch of questions, and then write a package.json for you. It will attempt to make reasonable guesses based on  existing  fields,  dependencies, and  options selected. It is strictly additive, so it will keep any fields and values that were already set. You can also use -y/--yes to skip the questionnaire altogether.  If  you pass --scope, it will create a scoped package. See Also · https://github.com/isaacs/init-package-json · npm help package.json · npm help version · npm help scope April 2020                                NPM-INIT(1)

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_33889429: Convert lowercase to uppercase in the case of excel file using shell script
Top-3 Scripts:
so_33889429: tmpf=`tempfile`.csv
ssconvert "pathtoyourexcelfile" "pathtoyourcsvfile"
cat $3 | tr "[:lower:]" "[:upper:]"  | tr -d "\\r\\000" > $tmpf
sed -i -e '1,1s/, $//' $tmpf
echo -n $tmpf
